title: Essential Key Metrics: Unlocking Their Impact in Data Analytics
content: Key metrics are the most crucial data points that businesses track to evaluate their performance, make informed decisions, and drive improvements. These metrics act as guiding indicators, helping organizations understand trends, identify problems, and measure success across various aspects of operations, marketing, finance, and customer engagement.  Unlike raw data, which can be overwhelming, key metrics offer a focused view of what truly matters. They transform complex datasets into meaningful insights that businesses can use to optimize strategies and improve efficiency.  Examples of Key Metrics in Different Domains  Business & Finance Metrics:     Revenue Growth Rate ‚Äì Measures how much a company‚Äôs revenue increases over time.   Gross Profit Margin ‚Äì Indicates profitability after deducting the cost of goods sold.   Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) ‚Äì The cost to acquire a new customer   Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) ‚Äì The total revenue a business can expect from a customer.   Oil & Gas Sector Metrics:     Production Efficiency ‚Äì Measures the ratio of actual production to potential production.   Operating Expenses per Barrel (OPEX/BBL) ‚Äì The cost of producing one barrel of oil.   Reserves Replacement Ratio (RRR) ‚Äì The amount of proven reserves added relative to production.   Downtime Percentage ‚Äì Tracks the time when equipment or operations are not running due to maintenance or failures.   Marketing Metrics:     Conversion Rate ‚Äì The percentage of visitors who complete a desired action (e.g., purchase, sign-up).   Click-Through Rate (CTR) ‚Äì The percentage of users who click on a specific link.   Return on Ad Spend (ROAS) ‚Äì Revenue generated per dollar spent on advertising.   Social Media Engagement ‚Äì The level of interactions (likes, shares, comments) on social media platforms.   Customer Experience Metrics:     Net Promoter Score (NPS) ‚Äì Measures customer loyalty and likelihood to recommend a product/service.   Churn Rate ‚Äì The percentage of customers who stop using a product/service.   Retention Rate ‚Äì The percentage of customers who remain over a given period.   Operational & Technology Metrics:     Inventory Turnover ‚Äì How quickly inventory is sold and replaced.   Average Resolution Time ‚Äì Time taken to resolve customer support tickets.   Website Load Time ‚Äì Measures the speed at which a webpage loads.   System Uptime Percentage ‚Äì Measures reliability and availability of IT systems.   How to Define & Use Key Metrics Effectively     Align Metrics with Business Goals ‚Äì Choose metrics that directly support business objectives.   Make Metrics Actionable ‚Äì A good metric should provide clear insights that drive action.   Use Benchmarks ‚Äì Compare performance against industry standards or past performance.   Track Metrics Over Time ‚Äì Consistency is key to identifying long-term trends.   Visualize Data for Clarity ‚Äì Use dashboards and reports to make data easy to interpret.   Choosing the Right Chart for Key Metrics  Selecting the right chart is crucial for effective data visualization in BI. A well-chosen chart simplifies insights, enhances decision-making, and avoids misinterpretation.     Identify the Type of Data Before selecting a chart, determine what you need to visualize:            Comparison ‚Äì Compare categories (e.g., sales by region).       Trends Over Time ‚Äì Track changes (e.g., monthly revenue).       Distribution ‚Äì Show frequency (e.g., customer age groups).       Proportion ‚Äì Display parts of a whole (e.g., market share)       Relationships ‚Äì Identify correlations (e.g., ad spend vs. sales).                Best Chart Types for Key Metrics             Bar/Column Charts ‚Äì Ideal for comparing data across categories (e.g., revenue by product).       Line/Area Charts ‚Äì Best for trends over time (e.g., monthly sales growth).       Histograms/Box Plots ‚Äì Show data distribution (e.g., order size frequency).       Pie/Donut/Treemap Charts ‚Äì Visualize proportions (e.g., budget allocation).       Scatter/Bubble Charts ‚Äì Analyze relationships (e.g., price vs. demand).                Advanced BI Charts             Combo Charts ‚Äì Mix line and bar charts for multi-metric analysis       Funnel Chart ‚Äì Show sales or conversion processes.       Waterfall Chart ‚Äì Track changes over time.       Gauge Chart ‚Äì Monitor KPIs (e.g., sales target progress).           Best Practices            Keep it simple & avoid clutter.       Use clear labels and colors effectively.       Be consistent with visual styles.       Test with stakeholders to ensure clarity.

title: Claim Report (Google Looker)
content: This data analysis and visualization report, constructed using Google Looker, transforms intricate datasets into lucid visual representations. Looker enables the conversion of complex information into insightful visuals, facilitating informed decision-making processes.

title: Managed Care (MQARE) Web
content: MQARE is a web-based application developed for the Managed Care division of Klinik SehatQ, part of the Sinarmas Group. This platform allows corporate clients to efficiently oversee healthcare processes and manage member portals, streamlining health service administration.  Technology: React JS, Next JS     üëâ See project

title: Healhtcare Summary Report
content: Using Power BI, I transformed complex datasets into clear and intuitive visualizations, enabling insightful interpretations. The visualizations highlight crucial information for healthcare providers, such as the top diseases, the most common patient demographics, and key performance metrics of healthcare professionals. These insights are presented in an accessible way to ensure quick understanding and informed action.  The analysis also uncovers patterns and trends within the data, helping stakeholders prioritize resources and address pressing healthcare challenges. For example, identifying the most prevalent diseases allows for targeted interventions, while recognizing patient demographics helps tailor services to meet specific needs effectively.  By leveraging these data-driven insights, decision-makers can optimize healthcare strategies to improve patient outcomes. The report serves as a practical tool for evaluating healthcare performance and fostering a more proactive approach to resource allocation and patient care delivery.

title: Python Faker, For Generating Desired Dummy Data
content: The Python Faker library is a powerful tool for generating synthetic data. It is widely used for testing, bootstrapping databases, anonymizing sensitive information, and creating realistic datasets for development and analysis. By leveraging Faker, developers can produce diverse and customizable data, such as names, addresses, emails, and more, without compromising privacy.  What is Python Faker?     Faker is an open-source Python library designed to generate fake data for various purposes.   It supports multiple locales, allowing users to create data in different languages and formats.   Ease of Use: Simple installation  pip install Faker   Usage (Case: Data Hospital Patient visits)  I am using this on Jupyter lab  Import library:  import pandas as pd import numpy as np from faker import Faker from datetime import datetime, timedelta import random   Here are the full code, for generating the data and the types as well:  # Initialize Faker fake = Faker()  # Sample ICD-10 codes (add more as needed) icd10_codes = [     # PENYAKIT KRONIS     # ü´Ä Cardiovascular Diseases     "I10",       # Essential (primary) hypertension     "I25.10",    # Atherosclerotic heart disease     "I50.9",     # Heart failure, unspecified     "I67.2",     # Cerebral atherosclerosis     "I69.30",    # Stroke, unspecified      # üç¨ Diabetes & Endocrine Disorders     "E11.9",     # Type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications     "E10.9",     # Type 1 diabetes mellitus without complications     "E11.65",    # Type 2 diabetes mellitus with hyperglycemia     "E66.9",     # Obesity, unspecified     "E03.9",     # Hypothyroidism, unspecified      # ü´Å Respiratory Diseases     "J44.9",     # Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), unspecified     "J45.909",   # Asthma, unspecified     "J96.10",    # Chronic respiratory failure     "J98.4",     # Other disorders of lung      # ü©∏ Kidney & Liver Diseases     "N18.9",     # Chronic kidney disease, unspecified     "N18.6",     # End-stage renal disease (ESRD)     "K76.9",     # Liver disease, unspecified     "K74.60",    # Cirrhosis of liver, unspecified      # üß† Mental Health & Neurological Disorders     "F20.9",     # Schizophrenia, unspecified     "F32.9",     # Major depressive disorder, single episode, unspecified     "F41.1",     # Generalized anxiety disorder     "G20",       # Parkinson‚Äôs disease     "G30.9",     # Alzheimer‚Äôs disease, unspecified      # ü¶¥ Musculoskeletal & Autoimmune Disorders     "M54.5",     # Low back pain     "M19.90",    # Osteoarthritis, unspecified site     "M32.9",     # Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), unspecified     "M05.79",    # Rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sites      # ü©π Chronic Pain & Others     "R52",       # Chronic pain, unspecified "K52.9",     # Noninfective gastroenteritis and colitis      # ü¶¥ Musculoskeletal & Pain Disorders     "M54.5",     # Low back pain     "M79.1",     # Myalgia     "M19.90",    # Osteoarthritis, unspecified site      # üß† Neurological & Mental Health     "F32.9",     # Major depressive disorder, single episode     "F41.1",     # Generalized anxiety disorder     "G47.33",    # Sleep apnea #"Flatulence",     "R17", #"Jaundice",     "R19", #"Abnormal feces",     "R21", #"Rash",     "R23", #"Spontaneous ecchymoses",     "R25", #"Abnormal involuntary movements",     "R26", #"Abnormal gait and mobility",     "R29", #"Abnormal postures",     "R30", #"Dysuria",     "R32", #"Unspecified urinary incontinence",     "R35", #"Polyuria",     "R36", #"Urethral discharge",     "R39", #"Genitourinary symptoms",     "S00", #"Superficial injury of head",     "S01", #"Open wound of head",     "S02", #"Fracture of skull",     "S03", #"Dislocation of joints of head",     "S04", #"Injury of cranial nerves",     "S06", #"Intracranial injury",     "S07", #"Crushing injury of head",     "S08", #"Traumatic amputation of head",     "S09", #"Other injuries of head",     "S13", #"Dislocation and sprain of neck",     "S14", #"Injury of nerves and spinal cord at neck level",     "S16", #"Injury of muscle at neck level",     "S17", #"Crushing injury of neck",     "S19", #"Other injuries of neck",     "S20", #"Superficial injury of thorax",     "S21", #"Open wound of thorax",     "S22", #"Fracture of rib(s), sternum",     "S23", #"Dislocation of thorax",     "S24", #"Injury of spinal cord at thoracic level",     "S25", #"Injury of blood vessels of thorax",     "S26", #"Injury of heart",     "S28", #"Crushing injury of thorax",     "S29", #"Other injuries of thorax",     "S30", #"Superficial injury of abdomen",     "S31", #"Open wound of abdomen",     "S32", #"Fracture of lumbar spine and pelvis",     "S33", #"Dislocation of lumbar spine",     "S34", #"Injury of spinal cord at lumbar level",     "S35", #"Injury of blood vessels in abdomen",     "S36", #"Injury of intra-abdominal organs",     "S37", #"Injury of urinary organs",     "S38", #"Traumatic amputation of abdomen",     "S39", #"Other injuries of abdomen"  ]   num_patients = 5000 patients = {     i: {"first_name": fake.first_name(), "last_name": fake.last_name()}     for i in range(1000, 1000 + num_patients) }  # Function to generate inpatient visit data def generate_inpatient_data(num_rows=100):     data = []      for _ in range(num_rows):         admission_date = fake.date_between(start_date="-2y", end_date="today")         length_of_stay = random.randint(1, 30)         discharge_date = admission_date + timedelta(days=length_of_stay)         admission_year = admission_date.year          billing_amount = round(random.uniform(500, 50000), 2)         insurance_covered = round(billing_amount * random.uniform(0.5, 1.0), 2)         out_of_pocket = billing_amount - insurance_covered          mortality_flag = random.choices([0, 1], weights=[95, 5])[0]         readmission_flag = random.choices([0, 1], weights=[85, 15])[0]          # Select a random patient         patient_id = random.choice(list(patients.keys()))         patient_info = patients[patient_id]          data.append({             "inpatient_id": fake.uuid4(),             "admission_date": admission_date,             "discharge_date": discharge_date,             "admission_year": admission_year,             "length_of_stay": length_of_stay,             "hospital_id": random.randint(1, 20),             "patient_id": patient_id,  # üî• Patient ID             "first_name": patient_info["first_name"],  # üî• First Name             "last_name": patient_info["last_name"],  # üî• Last Name             "doctor_id": random.randint(500, 1000),             "icd10_code": random.choice(icd10_codes),  # üî• BPJS and chronic ICD-10 Code             "department_id": random.randint(1, 10),             "bed_type": random.choice(["ICU", "General Ward", "Private Room", "Semi-Private"]),             "billing_amount": billing_amount,             "insurance_covered": insurance_covered,             "out_of_pocket": out_of_pocket,             "mortality_flag": mortality_flag,             "readmission_flag": readmission_flag,             "created_at": fake.date_time_this_decade(),             "updated_at": fake.date_time_this_decade()         })      return pd.DataFrame(data)  # Generate 100 rows df = generate_inpatient_data(10000)  # Save to CSV df.to_csv("results/fact_inpatient_visits_with_names.csv", index=False)  print("‚úÖ Fake inpatient data with patient names saved as 'fact_inpatient_visits_with_names.csv'") print(df.head())  # Preview the first 5 rows   Go to results/fact_inpatient_visits_with_names.csv path to see generated file  What ‚Äòs next?     Open your data and see the columns and data types   Adjust the data based on your need   For fact table, see the Dates column and ensure it is stick with date data type   Here is the result:
